awd_titl_txt: A Computational Approach to the Design of a Bioartificial Pancreas
awd_abstract_narration:
The main goal of this project is optimal design of an implantable, bioartificial pancreas for the treatment of Type 1 diabetes. The design is based on transplanting the healthy pancreatic cells into a gel medium (agarose gel), and encapsulating the cell-containing medium between two nanopore semi-permeable membranes to block the patient's immune cells from attacking the transplant. Encapsulated tissue transplantation is a novel approach to eliminating long-term use of immunosuppressants, which is one of the major challenges in transplantation therapy. The nanopore membranes are designed to block the immune cells while allowing passage of nutrients to keep the transplant viable as long as possible. The team around the collaborator Dr. S. Roy, Director of the Biodesign Laboratory at UCSF, is exploring a design of an implantable bioartificial pancreas, which will be implanted in the patient's arm, and connected to an artery and a vein similar to an arterio-venous graft. The key challenge in the development of the bioartificial pancreas is maintaining the survival of transplanted cells for an extended period of time, by providing sufficient access to nutrients, of which oxygen is the limiting factor. Involvement of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as high school students (particularly girls), in several aspects of this research is planned. The synergistic approach to the proposed project will provide a first, long-term viable implantable bioartificial pancreas without the need for immunosuppressive therapy.  
 
This project addresses the development of a multi-physics, multi-scale mathematical and computational model to study the design of an implantable, bioartificial pancreas for the treatment of Type 1 diabetes. The implantable, bioartificial pancreas will consist of an encapsulated chamber containing the transplanted pancreatic cells called islets, and a graft connecting the chamber to the patient’s cardiovascular system. The encapsulation chamber is modeled as a multi-layered poroelastic medium consisting of two semi-permeable membranes encapsulating a poroelastic gel holding the cells. The encapsulation strategy prevents the host’s immune cells from attacking the transplant. The proposed mathematical macro-scale model captures filtration of blood serum within the encapsulated multi-layered poroelastic islet chamber, and the fluid-structure interaction between the blood flow and the arterio-venous graft carrying blood to the islet chamber. To study oxygen supply to the transplanted cells, the fluid-structure interaction model is coupled to three nonlinear advection-reaction-diffusion models describing oxygen concentration in the tubular graft, in the poroelastic membrane, and in the islet chamber.  A novel partitioned, loosely coupled scheme for the numerical solution of this problem is proposed. At the micro-scale, a Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics solver will be used to study the influence of the fine poroelastic medium structure on oxygen supply to the transplanted cells. Deep Neural Networks will be used to study parameter estimation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing a mathematical model and computational solver to guide the design of an implantable bioartificial pancreas for treating Type 1 diabetes. The design involves transplanting healthy donor pancreatic cells into a poroelastic medium (agarose gel) and encapsulating this cell-containing medium between two nanopore semipermeable membranes. These membranes serve as a protective barrier, preventing the host's immune cells from attacking the transplant while allowing the passage of essential nutrients. Encapsulated tissue transplantation is a promising approach to eliminating the long-term need for immunosuppressants, which remains a major challenge in transplantation therapy.

A collaborator in this project, Dr. S. Roy, Director of the Biodesign Laboratory at UCSF, and his team have been exploring the design of an implantable bioartificial pancreas, intended to be placed in the patient's arm and connected to an artery and a vein, similar to an arteriovenous graft. See Figure 1. The primary challenge in its development is ensuring the long-term survival of transplanted cells, particularly by providing adequate oxygen supply, which is the key limiting factor.

 

To address this challenge, this project developed a multi-physics, multi-scale mathematical model and computational solver to evaluate novel design options that could enhance transplant viability:

(I) At the macro-scale, the model incorporates a fluid-structure interaction problem between blood flow, the arteriovenous graft, and a multi-layered poroelastic medium. A set of nonlinear advection-reaction-diffusion equations describing oxygen transport is coupled to this fluid-structure interaction. A novel partitioned, loosely coupled numerical scheme was developed to solve this system.

(II) At the micro-scale, a Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH) solver was used to analyze how the micro-scale poroelastic medium structure affects oxygen supply to the transplanted cells. Additionally, Deep Neural Networks were employed for parameter estimation.

 

Major findings:

It was found that a hexagonal channel micro-scale architecture within the poroelastic medium (scaffold) optimizes oxygen delivery to transplanted cells, offering a more effective alternative to current methods that rely on drilling vertical channels to enhance oxygen supply. See Figures 2, 3 and 4.

Additionally, incorporating multiple outlets along the encapsulated, multi-layered poroelastic medium significantly increases the filtration rate of blood plasma through the bioartificial pancreas. This, in turn, enhances oxygen availability to the transplanted cells, ultimately improving the longevity of the bioartificial organ.

This synergistic approach provides valuable insights into the design of the first long-term viable implantable bioartificial pancreas, eliminating the need for immunosuppressive therapy while ensuring the sustained survival of transplanted cells.

 

Intellectual Merit.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in:

1. Modeling: The development of a novel nonlinear mathematical model that integrates multiple physical processes across different scales, offering new mathematical insights and challenges.

2. Numerical Method Development: The integration of multi-scale computational approaches, including both a monolithic and a novel partitioned scheme at the macro scale, coupled with nano-scale SPH-based simulations, provides a new framework for optimizing the design of a bioartificial pancreas, complementing traditional biological approaches.

3. Biological Application: The computational findings, when combined with experimental data, hold strong potential for a transformative impact on the design of the first implantable bioartificial pancreas that eliminates the need for immunosuppressive therapy.

 

Broader Impacts.

The broader impacts of this project have been realized through:

1. Interdisciplinary mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral researchers.

2. Organizing an Interdisciplinary Conference at UC Berkeley, fostering collaboration among students, postdocs, and faculty.

3. Establishing a new partnership between the UC Berkeley Mathematics Department and the UC San Francisco Bioengineering Department.

4. Strengthening collaboration between Mathematics and Mechanical Engineering at Berkeley by developing and co-teaching a cross-listed course.

5. Building and maintaining an award website, engaging with local and national media, publishing in top-tier mathematics and interdisciplinary journals, and actively participating in national and international conferences through presentations and organization.
